context_evidences: - The legislations mostly ban the discussion, training, and/or orientation that the U.S. is inherently racist as well as any discussions about conscious and unconscious bias, privilege, discrimination, and oppression. These parameters also extend beyond race to include gender lectures and discussions. Reference: https://www.brookings.edu/articles/why-are-states-banning-critical-race-theory/ published on 2021-07-20 00:00:00

- The Republican-run legislature has been undeterred by nationwide controversy over Florida’s gun laws. The House defeated an effort to repeal the state’s “stand your ground” self-defense law in committee prior to the session, and last week sent the governor a bill that would allow citizens to brandish weapons or fire “warning shots” to fend off an attack. Reference: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-florida-guns/florida-bill-would-allow-guns-with-no-permit-in-natural-disasters-idUKBREA3A1UC20140411 published on 2014-04-11 21:07:15

- In the 114 th Congress, Representative Peter King and Senator Dianne Feinstein introduced the Denying Firearms and Explosives to Dangerous Terrorists Act of 2015 ( H.R. 1076 and S. 551 ). These proposals would give the Attorney General discretionary authority to deny firearms or explosives transfers to persons watchlisted as known or suspected terrorists if she deemed them to be "dangerous terrorists." These bills mirror a legislative proposal developed by DOJ and submitted to Congress in April 2007. First introduced in the 110 th Congress, these bills have been dubbed the "Terror Gap" proposal. Reference: https://www.everycrsreport.com/reports/IN10509.html published on 2016-06-16 00:00:00

- Pursuant to the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act ( P.L. 103-159 ), in November 1998 the FBI activated NICS for the purposes of determining an individual's firearms transfer and possession eligibility whenever an unlicensed individual seeks to acquire a firearm from a federally licensed gun dealer. Federal law enumerates several grounds that disqualify someone from firearms eligibility. However, being a known or suspected terrorist is not a federal firearms eligibility disqualifier. Reference: https://www.everycrsreport.com/reports/IN10509.html published on 2016-06-16 00:00:00

- The approach of some Republican-led state legislatures is a method for continuing to roll back racial progress regarding everything from voting rights to police reform. This is a horrible idea and does an injustice to our kids. Laws forbidding any teacher or lesson from mentioning race/racism, and even gender/sexism, would put a chilling effect on what educators are willing to discuss in the classroom and provide cover for those who are not comfortable hearing or telling the truth about the history and state of race relations in the United States. Reference: https://www.brookings.edu/articles/why-are-states-banning-critical-race-theory/ published on 2021-07-20 00:00:00

- The House voted 80-36 to move the bill (HB 209) to the state Senate, where a companion bill is ready for a floor vote that would send the measure to Governor Rick Scott later this month. Reference: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-florida-guns/florida-bill-would-allow-guns-with-no-permit-in-natural-disasters-idUKBREA3A1UC20140411 published on 2014-04-11 21:07:15
correction_response: This tweet is partially misinformed. In Florida, carrying a firearm without a license is only permitted in specific situations such as during a natural disaster evacuation, and not as a general rule. This is provided the person has no criminal record [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-florida-guns/florida-bill-would-allow-guns-with-no-permit-in-natural-disasters-idUKBREA3A1UC20140411]. As for books about Black people, there's no law making it a felony to carry such books. However, some legislations do ban discussions implying that the U.S. is inherently racist [https://www.brookings.edu/articles/why-are-states-banning-critical-race-theory/]. This doesn't equate to book burnings, but it does limit certain discussions in educational settings.
note_1_text: In Florida, it is a felony offense for a person knowingly to carry a concealed firearm without having a valid concealed carry license.  The offense includes penalties of up to 5 years in prison or 5 years of probation.  https://www.husseinandwebber.com/crimes/weapons-crimes/carrying-a-concealed-firearm/    http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0700-0799/0790/Sections/0790.01.html
note_2_text: In Florida, it is currently a felony to carry a concealed firearm without having concealed carry license punishable by up to 5 years in prison.     Florida House Bill 543 would legalize “conceal carry of weapons without a license” if passed.    http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0700-0799/0790/Sections/0790.01.html    https://www.flsenate.gov/Session/Bill/2023/543

refute_evidences: - The alleged assailant, 29-year-old Omar Mir Seddique Mateen, acquired these firearms from a federally licensed gun dealer about two weeks prior to the shooting. In so doing, he underwent and passed a background check through a computer system administered by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), known as the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS). In addition, the alleged assailant was employed as a state-licensed security guard and held a concealed carry weapons (CCW) permit . It has been reported that the state-issued security guard license might have allowed the alleged assailant to purchase these firearms with minimal background check requirements. Neither the Florida-issued security guard license nor his CCW permit would have exempted him from the federally required NICS background check, however. Reference: https://www.everycrsreport.com/reports/IN10509.html published on 2016-06-16 00:00:00

- In a crisis situation or evacuation for natural disasters such as hurricanes and wildfires, people with no criminal record would be allowed to carry a firearm without a permit, under a bill approved Friday by the Florida House of Representatives. Reference: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-florida-guns/florida-bill-would-allow-guns-with-no-permit-in-natural-disasters-idUKBREA3A1UC20140411 published on 2014-04-11 21:07:15

- Fitzenhagen said her bill would not allow convicted felons, on anyone else legally forbidden to own a gun, to carry weapons during an evacuation. The bill also applies to non-lethal stun guns, pepper spray and other defensive implements. Reference: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-florida-guns/florida-bill-would-allow-guns-with-no-permit-in-natural-disasters-idUKBREA3A1UC20140411 published on 2014-04-11 21:07:15
tweet_category: Human Rights, Social Issues, and Activism
tweet_text: In Florida carrying a firearm without a license is freedom but carrying a book about Black people is a felony. This is what systemic white supremacy looks like. I won’t be surprised if we see book burnings.
